content: @nikomatsakis What was the process last year for designing the survey? Did you take the previous year's survey, put it into a doc, and work on it in the doc, only transferring it to the survey website when you were happy with it?
Last year we didn't really make many changes, but I believe edits were done in the google form itself
I can't remember 100%
I was thinking that it would behoove us to spend a bit of time asking what questions we most want answered

I for one would like more data on what blocks adoption and on learning curve; also, things like how many people are using it and bouncing (that can be hard to know, of course, since such people may not respond to the survey)

nikomatsakis said:

Last year we didn't really make many changes, but I believe edits were done in the google form itself

I imagine any significant iteration would ultimately be easier to do in a separate doc
I’ll prepare a doc tomorrow that we can work on.
I would love to iterate in a doc - I think it has been a few years since we've made serious changes, and it's always been a bit rushed without time to gather feedback from teams

@nikomatsakis @Nick Cameron Here's a link to a hackmd with the survey questions. Currently this is an exact 1 to 1 copy of last year's survey. I add a bunch of comments for things that felt like they could use improvement or that came from the Improve the Rust Survey doc, but to begin with I'd like to leave the survey as is while we collectively get a feel for where we're coming from.

I've also created a doc to capture the high level questions we want to answer with the survey. These aren't (necessarily) questions we can or want to ask participants directly. Rather, these are the questions we hope to use the survey responses to answer. We can then use those a guide to make sure we think we're collecting the right data.

I'm a little disappointed this doesn't have any questions about devtools and no one thought to reach out to us ... I left some questions I'd like to see in https://rust-lang.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/131828-t-compiler/topic/Rust.20Annual.20Survey/near/246476913

No need to be disappointed. :blush:I'm not sure what you're referring to, but the high-level questions doc does have questions about devtools. Also, we're very much at the beginning here so if something is missing, it's most likely due to someone not yet having the time to write it down yet and not it being forgotten after careful consideration.
I'll definitely add your questions and post in the devtools channel (I looked in the list of streams but somehow missed that one)
@rylev most of the devtools teams are on Discord, not Zulip. I linked to here in #devtools: https://discord.com/channels/442252698964721669/459149107387170817/866720332744622081
Thanks!
There are questions about "tools developers use", like rust analyzer, but I didn't see cargo, rustdoc, rustfmt, or clippy mentioned.

Yep, and I hope we can add more about those tools. I hope I didn't get the impression this document was in any way done. The reason I posted in a bunch of channels was exactly because I knew a bunch of things were missing.
I was just worried we weren't going to be consulted at all :sweat_smile: as long as the questions go in before the survey goes out I'm happy :)

What editors do you use when writing Rust?

Should we ask what other terminals are used?
Doesn't seem like useful information to me? What would we do with that knowledge?
This might be slightly interesting if we want to know what and how we can optimize diagnostic output. I know the output is a certain way because some terminals don't support certain things.
But perhaps that's too niche to warrant a question
Yeah, I think the most important question there pretty much boils down to "do you use a version of Windows older than Windows 10".
(which I'm hoping we cover somewhere in the survey)

Josh Triplett said:

(which I'm hoping we cover somewhere in the survey)

We are not (we only ask about Windows but not which version - I'll add a note)
I'd love to know Windows version and macOS version, at least at a coarse granularity. That would help us inform support.
Not just target tier support, but also "how much effort should we put into supporting how old of a version of each OS".
also it'd be interesting intel vs m1 for macOS

@Josh Triplett @Pietro Albini Somethings like that could do what you want ? OS Kind (Windows, Linux, MacOS, BSD, ...) -> OS Name (if Linux or BSD, maybe also Windows with Server version ?) -> OS Version -> OS Architecture (x86_64, arm64, mips, ...)

I think we don't need that many different pieces of information. It would suffice to add "Windows 10 or newer" and "Windows older than Windows 10" as separate options, and likewise for a couple of macOS versions. (And yes, target architecture too.)
If the question hasn't been considered already, it may be useful to know if people regularly cross compile, and if so, if that is primarily using their host tools, a docker, or a CI system.
I think I've covered all the discussion on platform support here now: https://hackmd.io/2ltg9He8SWWjeVikALjjXA#Platform-Support

About rustdoc: I would ask if users feel things are missing/not enough in doctests, how often they use local/distant documentation

For rustdoc as well: might be worth discussing what we want to know from our users. On my side, I'd like to ask them a few things:

  • Do they have issues using rustdoc, and if yes which ones?
  • Are there missing features they'd want?

I also have other things in mind but they're too "open" (the one I asked are already super open...), like "how would improve the UX/UI?".
To be more specific about UI: what is one element of the interface they would use more often but it isn’t visible enough/distinct enough from the rest

For all UI/UX stuff, frankly my personal wish is i won't ever need to touch anything outside the UI of vscode+rust-analyzer... I hope everything can integrate into it, displaying HTML or other UI interface as necessary. (I'm a little biased, from Windows-user habit :))
That sounds extremely limiting ... How would you search the docs?

Speaking of tooling I'd like 2 questions asking:

  • Which editor are you using: [] emacs (and variants) [] vim/neovim [] vscode [] gnome builder [] atom? [] else
  • Which code assisting tools do you use most (multiple choice): [] rust analyzer (i.e. LSP) [] rls [] racer [] rustfmt [] clippy [] none
The document has moved to https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys. We can continue discussing here, but we can also capture feedback as issues on the repo.
I have some ideas, somewhat speculative. Should I send a PR to amend design.md?
I did that: https://github.com/rust-lang/surveys/pull/1

As an outsider, I'm curious: how do you decide how long to make the survey and what to prioritize? At least in organizational contexts, response rates drop off and ratings improve as survey length increases. Is that a concern?
I don't want to pretend that we have a strict methodology here. We'll just be talking through all the questions and making a judgement call if to include questions or not

From the previous couple of years, there hasn't been a noticable amount of response rate drop off due to survey length. Later questions in the survey move from ratings to rankings and discreet answer (eg. which of these tools do you use) which helps with some of the issues you raised.
As we look at adding to the survey and making adjustments, it is a concern that we will be keeping in mind (as well as potential order effects, redundancy, confusing wording, questions that are no longer relevant, and a couple other issues noted in the past).

Thanks for the answers, I happen to be working on a survey for my employer, and been thinking about these issues (e.g., we may have a dozen questions around topics and a few identity related questions for DEI purposes). The length seemed to be my main high level concern, but this is coming from an outsider perspective.
